text:
Since their release in 2016, Apple’s AirPods
have quickly become the most popular wireless
headphones in the world.

And their success has prompted third party
manufacturers to create similar products at
a more affordable price.

I’ve actually reviewed several of these
AirPod knockoffs in the past, including the
TWS-i7s, i9s, and i10s.

As you can see, the improvements made to each
generation brought them closer to the incredible
performance and design of Apple’s own AirPods.

And today, we’re going to take a look at
the latest pair of wireless headphones with

a design so similar to the AirPods that I
actually kept mixing up the two during my
few weeks of testing.

Now this video is sponsored by Knockies who
provided these Aire 2 headphones to me for
review.

And if you want to buy your own pair, you
can get 10% off using promo code APEX10 on
Knockies website.

So we’re going to start off the video by
unboxing the Aire 2’s, reviewing their features,

and then comparing them to the previous generation
i10s and Apple’s AirPods.

Now when it comes to the Aire 2’s outer
packaging, it may look familiar.

You can see the headphones on the front and
its charging case on the back, with the product
name on either side.

After lifting the lid we’re greeted by a
manual that describes the setup process and
functionality of the headphones.

And under that we find the charging case with
the Aire 2 headphones inside, along with a
small box which contains a lightning cable.

Yes, these knockoff AirPods actually use Apple’s
lightning connecter which is quite unusual
since previous generations used USB-C or micro-USB.
Now let’s take a look at the charging case.

It has a very familiar glossy white design
with a nice steep thumb scoop to pop open
the lid with ease.

And the hinge action is actually quite smooth
and satisfying.

On the front there’s a single LED indicator
used to display the charge level of the headphones

inside, in addition to displaying the charge
level of the battery case itself.

And if you’re wondering, “how can you
differentiate the charge level of the headphones
versus the case?”
Your answer is on the back.

There’s a button right here you can press
that’ll tell you the charging case’s battery
level by flashing this white LED.

One flash means it’s at 25% or lower, two
flashes for 50%, three flashes for 75, and
four flashes for 100%.

I actually really liked this feature since
I didn't have to remove the headphones from

their case, which is something you have to
do with Apple’s AirPods.

Unless of course, you check the battery level
from your iPhone in Today View.

And while we’re on the subject, I want to
point out an interesting difference between
the Aire 2 headphones and Apple’s AirPods.

In Today View you can see the battery level
of your AirPods and their charging case separately,

although with the Aire 2’s you can only
see the battery level of the headphones.

But what’s strange is that you can see the
Aire 2’s charging case status by lifting
the lid and triggering the pop-up window.

I’m not sure why this information couldn’t
be displayed in Today View, but I didn’t

find it to be an inconvenience since I just
used the charging case button to get an idea
of its remaining battery.

And on the bottom is its lightning connector,
the same port as my iPhone, which means I

don’t have to carry around an extra cable
just for my headphones.

But what’s even better is that the Aire
2’s have wireless charging, a huge benefit

that Apple actually charges a $40 premium
to include.

Now let’s take a closer look at the headphones
themselves.

Like the case, their design is virtually indistinguishable
from Apple’s AirPods, although they don’t
function exactly the same.

The Aire 2’s listing says they have touch
controls, and that’s exactly what they have.

In order to control music or answer calls,
all you have to do is touch this small opening
on either earbuds stem.
If you miss, the action won’t register.

The gesture can take some getting used to
in order to hit the right spot every time,

but I was able to control my music reliably
after just a few days of use.

Tapping once will play or pause music and
answer or end a phone call, a double tap will

skip to the next song, and a triple tap will
skip to the previous song.

I’m also pleased to report that you can
trigger Siri with these headphones by holding
your finger over the opening for a few seconds.

Now how do we actually pair these things to
our device?

Well, you might be surprised to discover that
the Aire 2’s actually have the same H1 chip
as Apple’s latest generation AirPods.

That means you can pair them with your iPhone
by simply lifting the lid, which’ll trigger

this pop-up window to connect quickly and
easily.

Now this feature is exclusive to iOS devices
so in order to pair with other smartphones

or computers, simply open the lid to enter
discoverable mode and locate the headphones
in your device’s bluetooth settings.

So we’ve covered the simple setup and straightforward
controls, but how do these Aire 2’s actually
sound?

That is the whole point of headphones after
all.

Well, of all the knockoff AirPods I’ve ever
used, these definitely sound the best.

It seemed to me that the AirPods did have
slightly fuller bass, but I had to switch

between the Aire 2’s and AirPods quite a
few times to catch that difference.

With some previous generations of AirPod knockoffs
I only recommended them for podcasts or phone
calls, since the audio quality was so poor.

But things have come along way in just a couple
years and I can confidently say these new

Aire 2 headphones have fantastic sound quality
that’s perfect for enjoying your favorite
music.

Although I should mention that these headphones
don’t get as loud.

I’d say they reach about 80-85% of the AirPods
max volume.

Now I don’t think this is necessarily a
bad thing since listening to loud music is
harmful to your ears.

But that is another notable difference between
the two headphones.

Now when it came to sustaining a reliable
bluetooth connection the Aire 2’s performed

better than their predecessor, although not
perfect.

They do feature the same Bluetooth 5.0 technology
as Apple’s AirPods, but software also plays
a large role in wireless headphone performance.

The good news is I didn’t have any problems
with the Aire 2s staying connected or synchronized.
They always played audio at the same time.

But when I watched YouTube videos, sometimes
the right headphone would start playing audio
a second or two before the left.

This delay happened about 25% of the time
but it never became annoying because once

the left headphone kicked in, the audio was
perfect.

Again, this only happened with YouTube videos,
music playback in Spotify and Apple Music
was always flawless.

I also want to mention that the Aire 2’s
wireless range is about 10 meters or 30 ft

without obstacles, and I found that to be
consistent with my testing.

And when it comes to battery life, you can
expect about three and a half hours of music

playback, with the charging case providing
three to four recharges.

So how do these Aire 2 headphones compare
to the previous TWS i10s that I reviewed just
six months ago?
Well, there’ve been a lot of notable improvements.

The wireless performance of the Aire 2s is
vastly superior.

You won’t experience any dropped connections,
lagging, or out-of-sync playback between the
two headphones.

You’ll also get better sound quality and
a much easier way to pair with iOS devices.

Not to mention the charging case having the
same lightning connector as your iPhone, which
just makes things easier when traveling.

And as I said before, the Aire 2’s have
QI wireless charging.

Which in my opinion is one of the biggest
reasons to upgrade.

Ever since I started wirelessly charging my
iPhone and AirPods, I could never go back

to fumbling with lighting cables that litter
my desk and nightstand.

But one of the coolest things about the Aire
2’s is their signature AirPod design.

I’ve never seen a company successfully replicate
the AirPods design this perfectly.

I mean, even the color of the LED light is
the exact same shade of green as the AirPods.

And if I switch the Aire 2’s and AirPods
right headphones, they actually fit perfectly
in the other’s charging case.

So I found the attention to detail with the
Aire 2’s design really incredible, and something
that sets it apart from other AirPod knockoffs.

But how exactly do they measure up to Apple’s
AirPods?
Well, let’s compare them side-by-side.

With the Aire 2’s, you get the same wireless
charging, touch controls, easy pairing process,
and great design as the AirPods.

Although there are differences between the
two.

AirPods can be paired to multiple devices,
they have slightly better bass, they deliver

five hours of music playback instead of three
and a half, they auto-pause after you remove

a headphone, and they have 30 meters or 100
feet of range as opposed to 10 meters.

But if you’ve been paying attention, you
may’ve noticed I left out a crucial piece

of information about the Aire 2’s and AirPods,
which is their price.

The AirPods with a wireless charging case
comes in at $200.

While the Aire 2’s, with so many comparable
features, is just $73.
That is quite a significant price difference.

In fact, you could buy two pairs of Aire 2
headphones and still save over $50 compared
to buying one pair of AirPods.

And remember, Knockies is offering you guys
10% off with the promo code APEX10, which

would bring the price down to $65.70, one
third the cost of the AirPods.

So if you consider everything we’ve discussed
in this video, you’ll realize it’s becoming
harder to justify purchasing Apple’s AirPods.

The differences in features between the Aire
2 headphones and AirPods is nominal.

And for many people, definitely aren’t worth
the $130 premium.

If you love the AirPods design, you can get
that for a third of the price.

If you love the AirPods easy pairing pop-up
window, you can get that for a third of the
price.

If you love the AirPods wireless charging
and touch controls, those features are all

available with the Aire 2 headphones for a
third of the price.

They deliver an incredible bang for your buck
and feature all the core capabilities that
you'd expect from wireless headphones.

But if you want some of those extra bells
and whistles that the AirPods provide and

money is no object, Apple’s $200 AirPods
are still some of the best wireless headphones
money can buy.

If you want to check out the Aire 2 headphones
you can find a link to those in the description.

And don’t forget to use promo code APEX10
at the checkout for an extra 10% off.

Alright guys thanks for watching, and I’ll
see you next time.
